Title: Përbindëshi (The Monster) (1965)
Notes: Banned for 25 years in Albania.[1]

Title: Lolita
Notes: Banned for being "obscene".[2]

Title: The Decameron
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1927 to 1936 and from 1938 to 1973.[3]

Title: The Decameron
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1927 to 1936 and from 1938 to 1973.[3]

Title: The 120 Days of Sodom (1789)
Notes: Banned by the Australian Government in 1957 for obscenity.[4]

Title: Droll Stories
Notes: Banned for obscenity from 1901 to 1923 and from 1928 to c. 1973.[5][6]

Title: Droll Stories
Notes: Banned for obscenity from 1901 to 1923 and from 1928 to c. 1973.[5][6]

Title: The Straits Impregnable
Notes: First edition published as a novel, second edition banned by the military censor in Australia under regulations of the War Precautions Act 1914.[7]

Title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
Notes: Banned from 1929 to 1965.[8][9]

Title: Rowena Goes Too Far (1931)
Notes: Banned in Australia because of customs belief that it "lacked sufficient claim to the literary to excuse the obscenity"[10]

Title: Brave New World
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1932 to 1937.[8]

Title: The Cautious Amorist
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1933 to 1953.[11]

Title: Age of Consent
Notes: Banned in Australia, briefly, in 1938.[12]

Title: Forever Amber (1944)
Notes: Banned by Australia in 1945 as "a collection of bawdiness, amounting to sex obsession."[13][14]

Title: Borstal Boy
Notes: Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958.[15]

Title: Another Country
Notes: Banned in Australia by the Commonwealth Customs Department in February 1963. The Literature Censorship Board described it as "continually smeared with indecent, offensive and dirty epithets and allusions," but recommended that the book remain available to "the serious minded student or reader." The ban was lifted in May 1966.[16]

Title: Ecstasy and Me
Notes: Banned in Australia from 1967 to 1973.[8]

Title: The World Is Full of Married Men (1968)
Notes: Banned in Australia in 1968.[8]

Title: The Stud (1969)
Notes: Banned in Australia in 1969.[8][further explanation needed]

Title: The Anarchist Cookbook
Notes: The book was refused classification in 1985 thus making it banned in Australia under the National Classification Code Table 1.(c) for publications that could "promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence"[8][17][18]

Title: How to make disposable silencers (1984)
Notes: An example of a class of books banned in Australia that "promote, incite or instruct in matters of crime or violence".[19][20]

Title: American Psycho
Notes: Sale and purchase was banned in the Australian state of Queensland. Now available in public libraries and for sale to people 18 years and older. Sale restricted to persons at least 18 years old in the other Australian states.[21]

Title: A Sneaking Suspicion (1995)
Notes: Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools on May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[22] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.

Title: The Peaceful Pill Handbook (2007)
Notes: The book was initially restricted in Australia;[23] after review, the 2007 edition was banned outright.[20][24][25]

Title: You: An Introduction (2008)
Notes: Banned by the New South Wales Department of Education and Communities from state schools on May 6, 2015, on the basis of a "potential risk to students in the delivery of this material, if not taught sensitively and in an age appropriate manner."[22] The ban was lifted May 18, 2015.

Title: No Game No Life (Volumes 1, 2, 9)
Notes: Light novel volumes banned in Australia due to their depiction, "in a way that is likely to cause offence to a reasonable adult, [of] a person who is, or appears to be, a child under 18".[26]

Title: The Sorrows of Young Werther
Notes: Banned by the authorities in the Austrian territories ruled by the Habsburg monarchy.[27]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Marx's works were banned in Austria after the country was annexed by Nazi Germany.[27]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Einstein's works published up to 1938 were banned in Austria, after it was annexed by Nazi Germany.[27]

Title: Mein Kampf (1925)
Notes: In Austria, the Verbotsgesetz 1947 prohibits the printing of the book. It is illegal to own[citation needed] or distribute existing copies.[28] Following the general prohibition of advocating the Nazi Party or its aims in § 3 and of re-founding Nazi organizations in § 1, § 3 d. of the Verbotsgesetz states: "Whoever publicly or before several people, in printed works, disseminated texts or illustrations requests, encourages or seeks to induce others to commit any of the acts prohibited under § 1 or § 3, especially if for this purpose he glorifies or advertises the aims of the Nazi Party, its institutions or its actions, provided that it does not constitute a more serious criminal offense, will be punished with imprisonment from five to ten years, or up to twenty years if the offender or his actions are especially dangerous."[28]

Title: Amar Fashi Chai (1999)
Notes: The book, set in the political and social context of Bangladesh, was banned by the then–Prime Minister of Bangladesh, Sheikh Hasina.[29] The book describes various aspects of Sheikh Hasina's character.[30][31]

Title: Rangila Rasul (1927)
Notes: Currently banned in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.[32]

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam. Rushdie received a fatwa for his alleged blasphemy.[33]

Title: Naree (1992)
Notes: Banned in Bangladesh in 1995,[34] though the ban was later lifted in 2000.[35]

Title: Lajja (1993)
Notes: Banned in Bangladesh,[36][37] and a few states of India. Other books by her were also banned in Bangladesh or in the Indian state of West Bengal. Amar Meyebela (My Girlhood, 2002), the first volume of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi government in 1999 for "reckless comments" against Islam and the prophet Mohammad.[38] Utal Hawa (Wild Wind), the second part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2002.[39] Ka (Speak up), the third part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladeshi High Court in 2003. Under pressure from Indian Muslim activists, the book, which was published in West Bengal as Dwikhandita, was banned there also; some 3,000 copies were seized immediately.[40] The decision to ban the book was criticised by "a host of authors" in West Bengal,[41] but the ban was not lifted until 2005.[42][43] Sei Sob Ondhokar (Those Dark Days), the fourth part of her memoir, was banned by the Bangladesh government in 2004.[44][45]

Title: Uitgeverij Guggenheimer ("Guggenheimer Publishers") (1999)
Notes: Banned in Belgium because this satirical novel offended fashion designer Ann Demeulemeester by making derogatory remarks about her personal looks and profession. A court decided the book was an insult to the individual's private life and ordered it to be removed from the stores.[46][47][48]

Title: The Mountain Wreath (1847)
Notes: Banned in Bosnian schools by Carlos Westendorp.[citation needed]

Title: Happy New Year (1975)
Notes: Banned in Brazil during the military dictatorship by order of the then Minister of Justice, Armando Falcão, under the accusation of "attacking morality and good habits". The author of the book, Rubem Fonseca, filed a lawsuit against the Brazilian government. In 1980, the case was tried for the first time and the judge upheld the ban, claiming that the work incited violence. The ban was lifted in 1985, with the end of the military dictatorship, but the book only received a new edition in 1989, when Fonseca appealed and won the case in court.[49][50]

Title: Droll Stories
Notes: Banned for obscenity in 1914.[51][6]

Title: Lady Chatterley's Lover
Notes: The unexpurgated United States edition was allowed to be imported by McClelland & Stewart in 1959.[52] The book's status as an obscene publication was not resolved until a ruling by the Supreme Court of Canada in 1962.[53]

Title: By Grand Central Station I Sat Down and Wept
Notes: Banned in Canada from 1945 to 1975 under the influence of Smart's family's political power due to its sexual documentation of Smart's affair with a married man.

Title: The Naked and the Dead (1948)
Notes: Banned in Canada in 1949 for "obscenity".[54]

Title: Lolita (1955)
Notes: Banned in Canada in 1956. The ban was not enforced on imports of the Putnam edition from the United States and was lifted in late 1958.[55][56]

Title: Peyton Place (1956)
Notes: Banned in Canada from 1956 to 1958.[56]

Title: How to Kill (series)
Notes: Banned in Canada in 1977.[57][58]

Title: The Hoax of the Twentieth Century
Notes: Classified as "hate literature" in Canada with the Royal Canadian Mounted Police destroying copies as recently as 1995.[59]

Title: The Turner Diaries
Notes: Classified as "hate literature" in Canada and subsequently banned from import into the country.[59]

Title: Lethal Marriage
Notes: Written by a newspaper reporter about the Paul Bernardo and Karla Homolka case, this book allegedly contains inaccuracies, additionally, complaints were received by the St. Catharines library board from the mother of a victim that led to the book being removed from all public library branches in the city.[59] As recently as 1999, this book was still unavailable to public library patrons in St. Catharines.[59]

Title: Lost Girls
Notes: Importation was initially prohibited on publication in 2006. The prohibition was overturned in October 2006 after a formal appeal by the publisher to the Canada Border Services Agency determined the book was not legally obscene.[60]

Title: How to Read Donald Duck
Notes: Banned in Pinochet's Chile. The Chilean army publicly burned copies of the book.[61]

Title: The House of the Spirits
Notes: Banned in Pinochet's Chile.[62]

Title: The Open Veins of Latin America
Clandestine in Chile
Notes: Banned in Pinochet's Chile. On November 28, 1986, the Chilean customs authorities seized almost 15,000 copies of Clandestine in Chile, which were later burned by military authorities in Valparaíso.[63]

Title: Jane Eyre (1847)
Notes: Jane Eyre was censored because the CCP deemed it socially corrupting to the youth of China during the Cultural Revolution.[64]
Author: Amy Corzine and Charlotte Brontë

Title: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland (1865)
Notes: Alice's Adventures in Wonderland was banned in the province of Hunan, China by the KMT's government, beginning in 1931, due to its portrayal of anthropomorphized animals which act with the same level of complexity as human beings. The censor General Ho Chien believed that attributing human language to animals was an insult to humans. He feared that the book would teach children to believe that humans and animals were on the same level, a result which would be "disastrous."[65]
Author: Lewis Carroll

Title: Various works
Notes: "Denounced by the Communists and Nationalists alike, Mr. Shen saw his writings banned in Taiwan, while mainland [China] publishing houses burned his books and destroyed printing plates for his novels. .... So successful was the effort to erase Mr. Shen's name from the modern literary record that few younger Chinese today recognize his name, much less the breadth of his work. Only since 1978 has the Chinese Government reissued selections of his writings, although in editions of only a few thousand copies. .... In China, his passing was unreported."[66]
Author: Shen Congwen (1902–1988)

Title: Life and Death in Shanghai (1986)
Notes: It is about the author's personal tortured experience during the Cultural Revolution.[67]
Author: Nien Cheng

Title: Soul Mountain (1989)
Notes: Gao Xingjian won the 2000 Nobel Prize in Literature for the book, however all of his works have been banned for having content critical of the CCP.[68][69]
Author: Gao Xingjian

Title: White Snow, Red Blood (1989)
Notes: Banned in 1990, and both the author and publishers were imprisoned for publishing it. The book includes information about atrocities committed by the Red Army during the siege of Changchun, the smuggling of opium by senior Party leader Wang Zhen during the Chinese Civil War, and claims that China's official description of the Lin Biao affair is inaccurate.[70][71]
Author: Zhang Zhenglong

Title: Wild Swans: Three Daughters of China (1991)
Notes: It talked about brutal political upheavals in China and purges of the Cultural Revolution.[72]
Author: Jung Chang

Title: Yellow Peril (1991)
Notes: Banned. The book contains episodes of a fictional collapse of Chinese communist rule.[73]
Author: Wang Lixiong

Title: Zhuan Falun (1993)
Notes: Banned in mainland China.[77]
Author: Li Hongzhi

Title: The Private Life of Chairman Mao (1994)
Notes: Banned for exploring Mao's private life.[78][79]
Author: Li Zhisui

Title: One Man's Bible (1999)
Notes: All of Gao Xingjian's works have been banned for having content critical of the CCP.[80][69]
Author: Gao Xingjian

Title: How the Red Sun Rose: The Origins and Development of the Yan'an Rectification Movement, 1930-1945 (2000)
Notes: Banned for exploring in detail Mao Zedong in the Yan'an Rectification and the internal struggles of the CCP.[81][82]
Author: Gao Hua

Title: Shanghai Baby (2001)
Notes: Banned. Burned in the street and the publisher was shut down for three months because of its sexual and drug-related content, which has been accused of being "immoral" by the government. Other writers have accused the book of plagiarism.[83][84]
Author: Wei Hui

Title: The Tiananmen Papers (2001)
Type: Compilation of selected Chinese official documents
Notes: Controversy about this book include authenticity of selected documents and selection bias.[85]
Author: Compiled by Zhang Liang

Title: Candy (2003)
Notes: Chinese government censored it because it was "a poster child for spiritual pollution".[86]
Author: Mian Mian

Title: Death Note (2003 – 2006)
Notes: Officially banned, but discussion and pirated copies are allowed to circulate.[87][88]
Author: Tsugumi Ohba

Title: Zhou Enlai: The Last Perfect Revolutionary (2003 or 2008)
Notes: Banned in China.[89][90]
Author: Gao Wenqian

Title: Buying a Fishing Rod for My Grandfather (2004)
Notes: All of Gao Xingjian's works have been banned for having content critical of the CCP.[91][69]
Author: Gao Xingjian

Title: I Love My Mum (2004)
Notes: A novella in which the relationship between Chinese citizens and their government are metaphorically portrayed as a cognitively impaired man in extreme sexual situations with their mother.[92]
Author: Chen Xiwo

Title: Will the Boat Sink the Water (2004)
Notes: Banned for exploring peasant protests. Sold an estimated 7 million pirated copies, despite being almost immediately banned by China's propaganda department.[93]
Author: Chen Guidi and Wu Chuntao

Title: Mao: The Unknown Story (2005)
Notes: Banned due to depicting Chairman Mao Zedong as a fascist leader against his people. Book reviews have also been banned.[94][95]
Author: Jung Chang

Title: Lingren Wangshi (2005)
Notes: The book, which documents the experiences of Peking Opera artists during the Anti-Rightist Campaign and the Cultural Revolution, was banned by the General Administration of Press and Publication in 2007.[96][97]
Author: Zhang Yihe

Title: Dream of Ding Village (2006)
Notes: Banned for discussing AIDS in rural China (Plasma Economy),[98] the ban had reportedly been lifted.[99]
Author: Yan Lianke

Title: Serve the People! (2008)
Notes: Banned for "slandering Mao Zedong", and depicting images of sex.[100]
Author: Yan Lianke

Title: Tombstone: The Great Chinese Famine, 1958-1962 [zh; fr] (2008)
Notes: Published in Hong Kong, banned for discussing the Great Chinese Famine.[101][102]
Author: Yang Jisheng

Title: Big River, Big Sea — Untold Stories of 1949 (2009)
Notes: It sold over 100,000 copies in Taiwan and 10,000 in Hong Kong in its first month of release, but discussion of her work was banned in mainland China following the book launch.[103]
Author: Lung Ying-tai

Title: Prisoner of the State (2009)
Notes: Banned. The book is memoirs by former Chinese General Secretary Zhao Ziyang.[104][105]
Author: Zhao Ziyang

Title: China's Best Actor: Wen Jiabao (2010)
Notes: Published in Hong Kong and banned in mainland China.[106] Author moved to the United States in 2012.[107]
Author: Yu Jie

Title: Bloody Myth: An Account of the Cultural Revolution Massacre of 1967 in Daoxian, Hunan (血的神话: 公元1967年湖南道县文革大屠杀纪实) (2012)
Notes: An account of murders in a rural district of China during Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution. Banned for 26 years and released in 2012.[108]
Author: Tan Hecheng

Title: Moving Away from the Imperial Regime (2015)
Notes: Banned. The book explores the unfulfilled promise of constitutional democracy, and another historian suggests that it may have been banned because the topic deals with the Chinese dynastic cycle.[109]
Author: Qin Hui

Title: Capital and Ideology (2019)
Notes: Banned for discussing China's income inequality and for refusing to accept censorship for a planned translation.[110]
Author: Thomas Piketty

Title: Unfree Speech: The Threat to Global Democracy and Why We Must Act, Now (2020)
Notes: Censored due to inciting secession. Taken out of libraries because of the Hong Kong national security law.[111]
Author: Joshua Wong

Title: The Chongzhen Emperor: Diligent Ruler of a Failed Dynasty (2023)
Notes: Censored due to popular comparisons between the final emperor of the Ming dynasty, the Chongzhen Emperor, and Xi Jinping.[112][113]
Author: Chen Wutong

Title: The White Disease (1937)
Notes: Banned by the government of the Second Czechoslovak Republic in 1938.
Author: Karel Čapek

Title: Animal Farm (1945)
Notes: Banned by the government in 1948.[114]
Author: George Orwell

Title: A Feast for the Seaweeds (Walimah li A'ashab al‑Bahr)
Notes: Banned in Egypt and several other Arab states, and even resulted in a belated angry reaction from the clerics of Al-Azhar University upon reprinting in Egypt in the year 2000. The clerics issued a fatwa banning the novel, and accused Haidar of heresy and offending Islam. Al-Azhar University students staged huge protests against the novel, that eventually led to its confiscation.[115][116][117]

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[33]

Title: One Day of Life (1980)
Notes: Banned by El Salvador for its portrayal of human rights violations.[118]

Title: I Didn't Do It for You: How the World Betrayed a Small African Nation (2005)
Notes: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for its criticism of President Isaias Afewerki.[119][failed verification]

Title: My Father's Daughter (2005)
Notes: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for political content.[119][failed verification]

Title: Scouting for the Reaper (2014)
Notes: Banned in Eritrea in 2014 for its criticism of civil liberties under President Isaias Afewerki.[119][failed verification]

Title: Les Mœurs
Notes: Officially banned in France in 1748.[120]

Title: Lolita (1955)
Notes: French officials banned it for being "obscene".[2]

Title: Suicide mode d'emploi (1982)
Notes: This book, reviewing recipes for committing suicide, was the cause of a scandal in France in the 1980s, resulting in the enactment of a law prohibiting provocation to commit suicide and propaganda or advertisement of products, objects, or methods for committing suicide.[121] Subsequent reprints were thus illegal. The book was cited by name in the debates of the French National Assembly when examining the bill.[122]

Title: Berlin Garden of Erotic Delights
Author(s): Erwin von Busse under the pseudonym "Granand"
Notes: Banned for "indecency" by courts in Berlin and Leipzig[123]

Title: Ivanhoe
Notes: Prohibited by Nazi Germany for featuring Jewish characters.[124]

Title: Oliver Twist
Notes: Prohibited by Nazi Germany for featuring Jewish characters.[124]

Title: The Communist Manifesto
Notes: Prohibited by several countries, including Nazi Germany.[125]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Zweig's books published up to 1933 were banned by the Nazis in that same year.[126]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Freud's books published up to 1933 were banned by the Nazis in that same year.[126]

Title: The Iron Heel
Notes: Banned by the Nazis along with two other London novels, Martin Eden and The Jacket.[126]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Brecht's books published up to 1933 were banned by the Nazis in that same year.[126]

Title: The Outline of History
Notes: Wells' book was banned in Nazi Germany.[126]

Title: The World of William Clissold
Notes: Banned in Nazi Germany in 1936. A further note to the banning order added that "all other works by the author" were to be suppressed.[127]

Title: All Quiet on the Western Front
Notes: Banned in Nazi Germany for being demoralizing and insulting to the Wehrmacht.[128][129]

Title: Die Gesteinigten
Notes: Banned and printed copies pulped.[130]

Title: The Story of Ferdinand
Notes: Banned in Nazi Germany.[131]

Title: The Jungle
Notes: In 1956, it was banned in East Germany for its incompatibility with Communism.[132][133]

Title: Auschwitz - Die Erste Vergasung - Gerüchte und Wirklichkeit
Notes: Confiscated by the Mannheim Regional Court in September 2012.[139] Unofficial title translation: Auschwitz, The First Gassing, Rumors and Reality

Title: Auschwitz - Tätergeständnisse und Augenzeugen des Holocaust
Notes: Confiscated by the Mannheim Regional Court in November 1994.[140] Unofficial title translation: Auschwitz - Confessions of Perpetrators and Eyewitnesses of the Holocaust

Title: Der Auschwitz-Mythos - Legende oder Wirklichkeit
Notes: Confiscated by the Stuttgart Regional Court in May 1982.[141] Unofficial title translation: The Auschwitz Myth - Legend or Reality

Title: Balisong - The Lethal Art of Filipino Knife Fighting
Author(s): Sid Cambell, Gary Cagaanan, Sonny Umpad, published by Paladin Press
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in May 1991.[142]

Title: Black Book Companion - State-of-the Art Improvised Munitions
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in July 1991.[143]

Title: Die Chemie von Auschwitz - Die Technologie und Toxikologie von Zyklon B und den Gaskammern - Eine Tatortuntersuchung
Notes: Confiscated by the Darmstadt Regional Court in March 2018.[144] Unofficial title translation: The Chemistry of Auschwitz - The Technology and Toxicology of Zyklon B and the Gas Chambers - A Crime Scene Investigation

Title: Cold Steel - Technique of Close Combat
Author(s): John Styres, published by Paladin Press
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in May 1991.[142]

Title: Deathtrap! Improvised Booby-Trap Devices
Author(s): Jo Jo Gonzales, published by Paladin Press
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in July 1991.[145]

Title: Dragons Touch - Weaknesses of the Human Anatomy
Author(s): Master Hei Long, published by Paladin Press
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in May 1991.[142]

Title: Endzeiten, Endspiele. Der Ausklang des jüdischen Jahrhunderts
Notes: Confiscated by the Kassel Regional Court in December 2000.[146] Unofficial title translation: End times, end games. The conclusion of the Jewish century

Title: Geheimakte Gestapo-Müller - Dokumente und Zeugnisse aus den US-Geheimarchiven (Band 1)
Notes: Confiscated by the Starnberg Regional Court in August 1996.[147] Unofficial title translation: Secret Files Gestapo Müller - Documents and Evidence from the US Secret Archives

Title: Geheimakte Gestapo-Müller - Dokumente und Zeugnisse aus den US-Geheimarchiven (Band 2)
Notes: Confiscated by the Starnberg Regional Court in January 1999.[148] Unofficial title translation: Secret Files Gestapo Müller - Documents and Evidence from the US Secret Archives

Title: Get Tough! How to Win in Hand-to-Hand Fighting
Author(s): William E. Fairbairn, published by Paladin Press
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in July 1991.[142]

Title: Grundlagen zur Zeitgeschichte - Ein Handbuch über strittige Fragen des 20. Jahrhunderts
Notes: Confiscated by the Tübingen Regional Court in March 1999.[149] Unofficial title translation: Fundamentals of Contemporary History - A Handbook on Controversial Issues of the 20th Century

Title: Der Holocaust auf dem Prüfstand - Augenzeugenberichte versus Naturgesetze
Notes: Confiscated by the Weinheim Regional Court in September 1993.[150] Unofficial title translation: The Holocaust under scrutiny - eyewitness accounts versus natural laws

Title: Der Holocaust-Schwindel
Notes: Confiscated by the Weinheim Regional Court in September 1993.[150] Unofficial title translation: The Holocaust Hoax

Title: Home Workshop Explosives
Author(s): Uncle Fester, published by Loompanics Unlimited
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in July 1991.[143]

Title: Homemade Guns and Homemade Ammo
Author(s): Ronald B. Brown, published by Loompanics Unlimited
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in July 1991.[143]

Title: Kardinalfragen zur Zeitgeschichte - Eine Sammlung kontroverser Stellungnahmen von Germar Rudolf alias Ernst Gauss zum herrschenden Zeitgeist in Wissenschaft, Politik, Justiz und Medien
Notes: Confiscated by the Weilheim Regional Court in March 1998.[151] Unofficial title translation: Cardinal Questions on Contemporary History - A collection of controversial statements by Germar Rudolf, alias Ernst Gauss, on the prevailing zeitgeist in science, politics, justice, and the media.

Title: Mein Kampf
Notes: In Germany, the copyright of the book was held by the State Government of Bavaria, and the Bavarian authorities prevented any reprinting from 1945 onward. This did not affect existing copies, which were available as vintage books. In 2016, following the expiration of the copyright, Mein Kampf was republished in Germany for the first time since 1945 as a commented edition by the Institut für Zeitgeschichte.[152] An uncommented reprint was confiscated by the Forchheim Regional Court in October 2016 for Incitement of masses.[153][154] Annotated editions are not affected by the confiscation.

Title: The Poisoner's Handbook
Author(s): Maxwell Hutchkinson, published by Loompanics Unlimited
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in May 1991.[142]

Title: Silent Death
Author(s): Uncle Fester, published by Loompanics Unlimited
Notes: Confiscated by the Munich Regional Court in May 1991.[142]

Title: Todesursache Zeitgeschichtsforschung
Notes: Confiscated by the Mannheim Regional Court in January 1996.[155] Unofficial title translation: Cause of death: Contemporary history research

Title: Vorlesungen über den Holocaust - Strittige Fragen im Kreuzverhör
Notes: Confiscated by the Mannheim Regional Court in March 2007.[156] Unofficial title translation: Lectures on the Holocaust - Controversial Questions in Cross-Examination

Title: Wahrheit sagen, Teufel jagen
Notes: Confiscated by the Schleswig Regional Court in February 2019.[157] Unofficial title translation: Wahrheit sagen, Teufel jagen

Title: Deep Wet Torture Handbook - Die 100 besten Frauenfolterfilme
Notes: Confiscated by the Neuburg an der Donau Regional Court in May 2007.[159] Unofficial title translation: Deep Wet Torture Handbook - The 100 Best Female Torture Films

Title: Lysistrata (411 BC)
Notes: Banned in 1967 in Greece because of its anti-war message.[160]

Title: Mein Kampf (1925)
Notes: Banned during the regime of Jorge Ubico along with anti‑Hitler writings such as by those of Hermann Rauschning in order to encourage political neutrality in WWII.[161]

Title: El Señor Presidente
Notes: Banned in Guatemala because it went against the ruling political leaders.[162]

Title: The Fugitive (Perburuan) (1950)
Notes: Banned in Indonesia in 1950, for containing "subversive" material, including an attempt to promote Marxist–Leninist thought and other Communist theories. As of 2006, the ban is still in effect.[163]

Title: All Chinese literature
Notes: Presidential Instruction No. 14/1967 (Inpress No. 14/1967) on Chinese Religion, Beliefs, and Traditions effectively banned any Chinese literature in Indonesia, including the prohibition of Chinese characters.

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[164]

Title: Interest
Notes: Banned by the government of Indonesia for subversive and/or anti-government themes.

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)
Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[33]

Title: The Gods Laugh on Mondays (1995)
Notes: Was banned in Iran after men torched its publication house.[165]

Title: Christianity not Mysterious
Notes: Banned by the Irish Parliament for contradicting the teaching of the Anglican Church. Copies of the book were burnt by the public hangman in Dublin.[166]

Title: Droll Stories
Notes: Banned for obscenity in 1953. The ban was lifted in 1967.[6]

Title: Married Love
Notes: Banned by the Irish Censorship Board for discussing birth control.[167]

Title: And Quiet Flows the Don
Notes: The English translations of Sholokhov's work were banned for "indecency".[168]

Title: Elmer Gantry
Notes: Elmer Gantry was banned in the Irish Free State.[169]

Title: The House of Gold
Notes: The first book to be banned by the Irish Free State for alleged "indecency". Republished in 2013.[170]

Title: A Farewell to Arms
Notes: Suppressed in the Irish Free State.[168]

Title: Marriage and Morals
Notes: Suppressed in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education, birth control and open marriages.[168]

Title: Commonsense and the Child
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State for advocating sex education for adolescents.[168]

Title: The Bulpington of Blup
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[169]

Title: Brave New World
Notes: Banned in Ireland in 1932, allegedly because of references of sexual promiscuity.[167]

Title: The Work, Wealth and Happiness of Mankind
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[169]

Title: Men of Good Will
Notes: The English translations of Romains' novel sequence were banned in the Irish Free State.[168]

Title: The Martyr
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[169]

Title: The Laws of Life
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State for discussing sex education and Calendar-based contraceptive methods – even though The Laws of Life had been granted a Cum permissu superiorum endorsement by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Westminster.[171]

Title: Honourable Estate
Notes: Banned in the Irish Free State.[168]

Title: I Knock at the Door

Title: Dutch Interior
Notes: Banned in Ireland.[171]

Title: The Tailor and Ansty
Notes: Banned by the Irish censors for discussing sexuality in rural Ireland.[172]

Title: Borstal Boy
Notes: Banned in Ireland in 1958. The Irish Censorship of Publications Board was not obliged to reveal its reason but it is believed that it was rejected for its critique of Irish republicanism and the Catholic Church, and its depiction of adolescent sexuality.[15]

Notes: Banned by Ireland's censorship board in 1960 for its explicit sexual content.[173][174]

Title: The Lonely Girl (1962)
Notes: Banned in Ireland in 1962 after Archbishop John Charles McQuaid complained personally to Justice Minister Charles Haughey that it "was particularly bad".[174]

Notes: Banned in Ireland for obscenity.[175]

Title: My Secret Garden
Notes: Banned in Ireland for its sexual content.[176]

Notes: Banned in Fascist Italy because of its antimilitarism (currently not banned).[179]

Title: A Farewell to Arms
Notes: Banned in Fascist Italy for depicting the Italian Army's defeat at the Battle of Caporetto (currently, this book is not banned).[180]

Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[33]

Title: The Da Vinci Code

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)

Title: Onward Muslim Soldiers

Title: Fifty Shades Trilogy

Title: The Mask of Sanity (2017)

Title: Rebirth: Reformasi, Resistance, and Hope in New Malaysia
Notes: Banned for containing insulting elements to the Malaysian coat of arms which is likely to be prejudicial to public order, security, national interest, alarm public opinion and contrary to any law, and therefore is "absolutely prohibited throughout Malaysia".[186]

Title: Gay is OK! A Christian Perspective (2013‍–‍2022)
Notes: Banned for attempting to promote homosexual culture in Malaysia, which goes against religious and cultural sensitivities in the country.[187] In 2022, the ban was challenged through a judicial review petition in High Court of Kuala Lumpur. The court quashed the ban and ordered the Home Ministry of Malaysia to pay RM 5000 to the author.[188]

Title: Peichi (Tamil: பேய்ச்சி)
Notes: Banned for containing pornographic and immoral content.[189] Notably, it was the first Tamil language publication to be banned in the country.

Title: A Million Kisses in Your Lifetime
Notes: The ministry explained on January 7, 2025, that the ban is part of a preventive measure to stop the spread of ideologies and movements that conflict with Malaysia's multicultural values.

Title: Lose You to Find Me
Notes: The ministry explained on January 7, 2025, that the ban is part of a preventive measure to stop the spread of ideologies and movements that conflict with Malaysia's multicultural values.

Title: Punai
Notes: The ministry explained on January 7, 2025, that the ban is part of a preventive measure to stop the spread of ideologies and movements that conflict with Malaysia's multicultural values.

Title: Scattered Showers
Notes: The ministry explained on January 7, 2025, that the ban is part of a preventive measure to stop the spread of ideologies and movements that conflict with Malaysia's multicultural values.

Title: When Everything Feels Like The Movie
Notes: The ministry explained on January 7, 2025, that the ban is part of a preventive measure to stop the spread of ideologies and movements that conflict with Malaysia's multicultural values.

Title: What If It's Us
Notes: The ministry explained on January 7, 2025, that the ban is part of a preventive measure to stop the spread of ideologies and movements that conflict with Malaysia's multicultural values.

Title: My Shadow is Purple
Notes: Banned for attempting to promote homosexual culture in Malaysia, which goes against religious and cultural sensitivities in the country. The home ministry said these books have been banned under Section 7(1) of Act 301 as they are considered 'undesirable publications' on January 21, 2025, and was later publicly announced on February 8.

Title: Koleksi Puisi Masturbasi
Notes: Banned for its suggestive name and immoral content. The home ministry said these books have been banned under Section 7(1) of Act 301 as they are considered 'undesirable publications' on January 22, 2025, and was later publicly announced on February 8.

Title: All That's Left in the World
Notes: Banned for attempting to promote homosexual culture in Malaysia, which goes against religious and cultural sensitivities in the country. The home ministry said these books have been banned under Section 7(1) of Act 301 as they are considered 'undesirable publications' on January 22, 2025, and was later publicly announced on February 8.

Title: Notre ami le roi (1993)
Type: Biography of Hassan II of Morocco
Notes: Banned in Morocco. This book is a biography of King Hassan and examines cases of torture, killing, and political imprisonment said to have been carried out by the Moroccan government at his orders.[190]

Title: Le roi prédateur (2012)
Notes: Banned in Morocco. This book makes allegedly "defamatory" accusations of corruption against Mohammed VI of Morocco, after investigating the exponential growth of his wealth.[191][192]

Title: The Rape of Sita (1993)
Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Hindu goddess.

Title: The Satanic Verses (1988)

Notes: Banned for blasphemy against Islam.[193]

Notes: Banned for irredentist views regarding the country's neighbors.[193][failed verification]

Title: The Cover-up General
Notes: Banned in the Netherlands by court order in 2015 as a former spy of Dutch military intelligence claimed she was described falsely in this Srebrenica book.[194] Ban lifted by the Court of Appeal of The Hague in 2016.[195][196]

Title: Lolita (1955)
Notes: Banned for being "obscene"; uncensored in 1964.[2]

Title: Borstal Boy
Notes: Banned shortly after its ban in Ireland in 1958. It was allowed to be published in New Zealand in 1963.[15]

Title: The Peaceful Pill Handbook (2007)

Notes: Banned in New Zealand in 2015; subsequently unrestricted in the same year.[198]

Title: My Watch (2005)

Notes: Sexually explicit.[200]

Title: Albertine
Notes: Sexually explicit.[201]

Notes: Swami Dayananda's religious text Satyarth Prakash was banned in some princely states and in Sindh in 1944 and is still banned in Sindh.[205]

Notes: Currently banned in India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.[32]

Notes: Research on the literary works by Bienvenido Lumbera, who was imprisoned during the Martial Law period under President Ferdinand Marcos. Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti‑government".[211]

Title: Teatro Political Dos
Notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti‑government". The works are previously published under the auspices of the KWF.[211]

Title: Kalatas: Mga Kuwentong Bayan at Kuwentong Buhay
Notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti‑government". The works are previously published under the auspices of the KWF.[211]

Notes: Banned in 2022 by the Commission on the Filipino Language (KWF) from public libraries and schools for being "anti‑government[211]

Title: História do Mundo para as Crianças [pt]
Notes: The book was banned by the Portuguese government without any clear reason. According to the author, one possible reason was because he was from the "current of thought what claims that the discovery of Brazil happened 'by random'" or by the fact he "have registered the history of the 1600 years cut to the Arabian navy by Vasco da Gama".[213]

Title: New Portuguese Letters (Novas Cartas Portuguesas)
Author(s): Maria Isabel Barreno, Maria Teresa Horta and Maria Velho da Costa
Notes: Banned as "pornographic and an offense to public morals"; authors charged with "abuse of the freedom of the press" and "outrage to public decency"; uplifted after the Carnation Revolution in 1974.[214]

Notes: Banned in Qatar in 2012.[215][further explanation needed]

Title: The Man Who Wouldn't Stand Up (2012)

Title: Thalia
Notes: Banned in the Roman Empire in the 330's+ for contradicting Trinitarianism. All of Arius writings were ordered burned and Arius exiled, and presumably assassinated for his writings.[218] Banned by the Catholic Church for the next thousand plus years.[citation needed]

Title: Quran

Title: Apocalypse Culture

In 2006, shortly after Ultra.Kultura (Ультра.Культура) published a Russian edition combining Apocalypse Culture and Apocalypse Culture II as a single volume titled Культура времен Апокалипсиса, the volume was banned by Kremlin decree.

Title: Siege
Notes: Anthology of essays advocating for neo-Nazi revolution through terrorism. Banned on August 14, 2023.[224]

Title: Works
Notes: Banned in Soviet Union since 1923 on proposal of Nadezhda Krupskaya. All works were placed on the list of forbidden books and kept in libraries only for restricted, authorized use.[225]

Title: Animal Farm
Notes: Completed in 1943, Orwell found that no publisher would print the book, due to its criticism of the USSR, an important ally of Britain in the War.[226] Once published, the book was banned in the USSR and other communist countries.[227]

Title: Nineteen Eighty-Four (1949)
Notes: Banned by the Soviet Union[128] in 1950, as Stalin understood that it was a satire based on his leadership. It was not until 1990 that the Soviet Union legalised the book and it was re-released after editing.[228]

Title: Doctor Zhivago
Notes: Banned in the Soviet Union until 1988 for criticizing life in Russia after the Russian Revolution. When its author, Boris Pasternak, won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1958, he was forced to reject it under government pressure.[128]

Title: One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich (1962)
Notes: Banned from publication in the Soviet Union in 1964.[163]

Title: The First Circle (1968)
Notes: After Nikita Khrushchev was removed from power in 1964, all extant and forthcoming works by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn were banned in the Soviet Union. This work details the lives of scientists forced to work in a Stalinist research center.[229]

Title: The Gulag Archipelago (1973)
Notes: Banned in the Soviet Union because it went against the image the Soviet Government tried to project of itself and its policies.[230] However, it has been available in the former Soviet Union since at least the 1980s. In 2009, the Education Ministry of Russia added The Gulag Archipelago to the curriculum for high-school students.[231]

Title: Works
Notes: Banned by Habsburg Monarchy of Spain for perceived heresy.[254]

Title: Works
Notes: Voltaire's entire body of work was banned by the Bourbon Monarchy of Spain, after it was condemned by the Spanish Inquisition.[255]

Title: Works
Notes: All of Blasco Ibáñez's books were banned by the Franco government in 1939.[256]

Title: A Short History of the World
Notes: An expanded, Spanish‑language translation of A Short History of the World, discussing recent world events, was banned by Spanish censors in 1940. This edition of A Short History was not published in Spain until 1963. In two 1948 reports, Spanish censors gave a list of objections to the books's publication. These were that the book "shows socialist inclinations, attacks the Catholic Church, gives a twisted interpretation of the Spanish Civil War and the Spanish National Movement, and contains 'tortuous concepts'."[257]

Title: Ulysses
Notes: The complete 1945 Spanish‑language translation of Ulysses was suppressed by the Spanish authorities until 1962.[258]

Title: The Story of Ferdinand
Notes: Banned in Francoist Spain.[131]

Title: Homage to Catalonia
Notes: Banned in Francoist Spain for its support of the Republican faction during the Spanish Civil War.[259]

Title: For Whom the Bell Tolls
Notes: Suppressed by the Spanish authorities until 1968.[260]

Notes: Banned until 1954; published in Argentina.[261]

Notes: Banned in Francoist Spain for criticizing Christianity, and for mentioning the Bombing of Guernica by the Axis air forces.[262]

Title: The Spanish Labyrinth
Notes: Banned in Francoist Spain because of its strong criticism of the Nationalist Faction's actions during the Spanish Civil War.[263]

Title: The Second Sex

Title: The Hive
Notes: Banned by censors of Francoist Spain.[265]

Notes: Banned in Thailand for its criticism of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.[270]

Title: Betrayed By My Leader

Title: Animal Farm
Notes: In 2002, the novel was banned in the schools of the United Arab Emirates, because it contained text or images that would go against Islamic values, most notably an anthropomorphic, talking pig as the leader of the farm. However, the ban is no longer enforced and has been recently lifted.[163]

Title: Areopagitica
Notes: Banned in the Kingdom of England for political reasons.[274]

Title: Fanny Hill or Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure
Notes: Banned in the UK until after the Second World War.[275]

Notes: Banned in the UK and author charged with treason for supporting the French Revolution.[160]

Title: Ulysses (1922)
Notes: Banned in the UK until 1936.[278][279]

Title: The Well of Loneliness (1928)
Notes: Banned in the UK in 1928 for its lesbian theme; republished in 1949.[280]

Title: Boy
Notes: Prosecuted in 1934 after Hanley's publisher Boriswood lost a court case against a charge of obscenity.[281] Reprinted in 1992 by Penguin Books and André Deutsch.

Title: Lolita
Notes: Banned for being "obscene".[2]

Title: Last Exit to Brooklyn
Notes: Banned in Soho for frank depictions of taboo subjects, such as drug use, street violence, homosexuality, gender identity and domestic violence.[283]

Title: Spycatcher
Notes: Banned in the UK from 1985 to 1988 for revealing secrets. Wright was a former MI5 intelligence officer and his book was banned before it was even published in 1987.[284][285]

Title: Lord Horror
Notes: Banned in England in 1991 where it was found obscene; it is currently the last book to be banned in the UK. The judge ordered the remaining print run to be destroyed. The ban was lifted in the Appeal Court in July 1992 but the book remains out of print.[286]

Title: The Anarchist Cookbook
Notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[287][288]

Title: Kill or Get Killed
Notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[287][288]

Title: Put 'Em Down. Take 'Em Out. Knife Fighting Techniques From Folsom Prison
Notes: Criminal due to containing information useful to terrorists.[287][288]

Title: The Meritorious Price of Our Redemption (1650)
Notes: The first book banned in the New World. Pynchon, a prominent leader of the Massachusetts Bay Colony who, in 1636, founded the City of Springfield, Massachusetts, wrote this explicit critique of Puritanism, published in London in 1650. That year, several copies made their way back to the New World. Pynchon, who resided in Springfield, was unaware that his book suffered the New World's first book burning, on the Boston Common. Accused of heresy by the Massachusetts General Court, Pynchon quietly transferred ownership of the Connecticut River Valley's largest land‑holdings to his son, and then suffered indignities as he left the New World for England. It was the first work banned in Boston.[289]

Title: Fanny Hill or Memoirs of a Woman of Pleasure
Notes: Banned in the U.S. in 1821 for obscenity, then again in 1963. This was the last book ever banned by the U.S. government. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[290][291][129] See also Memoirs v. Massachusetts.

Title: Candide
Notes: Seized by U.S. Customs in 1930 for obscenity. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[290][291][160]

Title: Uncle Tom's Cabin (1852)
Notes: Banned in the Confederate States during the Civil War because of its anti‑slavery content.

Title: Elmer Gantry
Notes: Banned in Boston, Massachusetts, Kansas City, Missouri, Camden, New Jersey, and other U.S. cities, this novel by Sinclair focused on religiosity and hypocrisy in the United States during the 1920s by depicting a preacher (the Reverend Dr. Elmer Gantry) as a protagonist who preferred easy money, alcohol, and "enticing young girls" to saving souls, while converting a traveling tent revival crusade into a profitable and permanent evangelical church and radio empire for his employers. Elmer Gantry also widely denounced from pulpits across the United States at the time of its initial publication. U.S. obscenity laws were overturned in 1959 by the Supreme Court in Kingsley Pictures Corp. v. Regents.[290][291][292][293]

Title: Lady Chatterley's Lover (1928)
Notes: Temporarily banned in the United States for violation of obscenity laws; the ban was lifted in 1959.[clarification needed][6]

Title: Tropic of Cancer (1934)
Notes: Banned in the U.S. in the 1930s until the early 1960s, seized by US Customs for sexually explicit content and vulgarity. The rest of Miller's work was also banned by the U.S.[294] Also banned in South Africa until the late 1980s.[295]

Title: The Grapes of Wrath (1939)
Notes: Was temporarily banned in many places in the U.S. In the state of California in which it was partially set, it was banned for its alleged unflattering portrayal of residents of the area.[296]

Title: Forever Amber (1944)
Notes: Banned in fourteen states in the U.S. Ban was lifted by an appeals court judge.[13][14]

Title: Memoirs of Hecate County (1946)
Notes: Banned in the state of New York by the Supreme Court.[297]

Title: Howl (1955)
Notes: Copies of the first edition seized by San Francisco Customs for obscenity in March 1957; after trial, obscenity charges were dismissed.[298]

Title: Naked Lunch (1959)
Notes: Banned by Boston courts in 1962 for obscenity, but that decision was reversed in 1966 by the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court.[299]

Title: United States – Vietnam Relations, 1945–1967: A Study Prepared by the Department of Defense (1971)
Author(s): Robert McNamara and the United States Department of Defense
Notes: Also known as the Pentagon Papers. U.S. President Nixon attempted to suspend publication of classified information. The restraint was lifted by the U.S. Supreme Court in a 6–3 decision.[300] See also New York Times Co. v. United States.

Title: The Federal Mafia
Year unbanned: Available for free, but denied for sale as deceptive commercial speech, appeal affirmed in 2004.
Notes: An injunction was issued by a US District Court in Nevada under 26 U.S.C. § 7408 against Irwin Schiff and associates Cynthia Neun and Lawrence Cohen against the sale of this book by those persons as the court found that the information it contains is fraudulent.[301]

Title: Operation Dark Heart (2010) – oop
Author(s): Army Reserve Lt. Col. Anthony Shaffer
Year unbanned: In 2013, 198 of 433 redactions of classified material reinstated. In 2015, testimony to Congress was permitted.
Notes: In September 2010, the United States Department of Defense (DoD) overrode the Army's January approval for publication. The DoD then purchased and destroyed all 9,500 first edition copies, citing concerns that it contained classified information which could damage national security. The publisher, St. Martin's Press,[302] in conjunction with the DoD created a second, redacted edition; which contains blacked out words, lines, paragraphs, and portions of the index.[303]

Title: The Open Veins of Latin America
Works
Notes: Author in exile since 1994 and all his works are banned for being critical of the government.[304][305][306]

Title: La İlahe İllallah Ne Demek Biliyor musun?
Notes: Contains ideas of extremism and terrorism[307]

Title: Demokratiya - bu dindir!
Notes: Contains ideas of extremism and terrorism[307]

Title: Animal Farm
Notes: Vietnamese translations are banned[308][309] on the grounds of "promoting false socialism ideology" [310]

Title: Nineteen Eighty-Four
Notes: The book was unable to get certification for publication, thus making it banned in Vietnam.[308]

Title: Mourning Headband for Hue: An Account of the Battle for Hue, Vietnam 1968 (Một lần nhân vật Mậu Thân trong “Giải Khăn Sô Cho Huế")
Notes: The book was banned for its criticism of the actions of the national liberation front and for acknowledging the 1968 Huế massacre[311]

Title: Paradise of the Blind
Notes: Banned in Vietnam for criticism on the political party in control.[312]

Title: No Man's Land
Notes: Banned in Vietnam for criticism of the Vietnamese Communist Party.[313][314][315]

Title: Politics for Everyone (Chính Trị Bình Dân)
Notes: Banned in Vietnam on the grounds of political sensitivity.[316][317][318]

Title: The Road To Serfdom
Notes: Banned due to criticism of the socialist state, especially the planned economy which would inevitably lead to totalitarianism.[319][320]

Title: A Tale for 2000 (Chuyện Kể Năm 2000)
Notes: The author talked about his experience being imprisoned in a "Vietnamese Gulag" for "Anti-revolutionary propaganda"[321] The book was banned with all copies ordered to be destroyed following the Decision No. 395 Regulation of the then Ministry of Culture and Information for violating Clauses 1 and 2 of the Article 33, Publishing Law which prohibits works criticising the Vietnamese Communist Party and propaganda going against the interests of the state.[322][323][324]

Title: The Winning Side (Bên Thắng Cuộc)
Notes: Due to publications within Vietnam had refused to publish, the author decided to print himself and released it on Amazon. Although it has not been officially banned, the Vietnamese government had seized and question those who had them.[325][326][327][328] This book was considered to be significant as it has provided insights that scholars had never seen before, while it had received a lot of criticism from Vietnamese state media.[329][330]

Title: A Dusty Wind (Một Cơn Gió Bụi)
Notes: Banned in Vietnam for being "inappropriate, not objective, and containing unverified information" thus violating the Vietnamese Publishing Law, which tends to happen to the biographies of historical characters deemed to be "controversial"[a] by the government.[331][332][333]

Title: The Nickel‑Plated-Feet Gang During the Occupation (Les Pieds nickelés dans le maquis)
Notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1945.[334]

Title: About a Silence in Literature
Notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1951.[334][citation needed]

Title: The New Class: An Analysis of the Communist System (1957)
Notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1957; author sentenced for enemy propaganda to seven years in prison, prolonged to 13 years in 1962.[335]

Title: Curved River
Notes: In 1963 in Yugoslavia withdrawn by the publisher (Nolit) at request of SDB officials.[335]

Title: Dictionary of Modern Serbo-Croatian Language
Notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1966, at request of Mirko Tepavac, because "some definitions can cause disturbance among citizens".[335]

Title: A Message to Man and Humanity
Notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1967 for "false and wicked claims, and enemy propaganda that supports pro-Chinese politics".[335]

Title: On Fierce Wound – Fierce Herb
Notes: Withdrawn from sales and destroyed after the decision of the Municipal Committee of the League of Communists of Kraljevo in Kraljevo, Yugoslavia in 1967.[335]

Title: Thoughts of a Corpse
Notes: Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1983; republished in 2004.[334]

Title: Storytellers II
Notes: Withdrawn from print in Yugoslavia in 1964 because it contained stories by Dragiša Vasić.[335]

Title: Castration of the Wind
Notes: Written in Tuzla prison in 1984. Banned in Yugoslavia by court order in 1984; republished in 2005.[334]
